> > That certainly makes sense. It raises the question of how bilateral sym=
metry arose in biological organisms.

I have no link to literature or any k=
ind of evidence, but with regard to this paper I was wondering what kind of=
 creatures would emerge if you would start with an organism that has spheri=
cal symmetry (as far as you can represent spherical symmetry with voxels ;)=
) encoded through a CPPN. This ancestor organism would be something like a =
unicellular organism in nature. Starting with a CPPN of such an organism wo=
uld mean that radial and bilateral symmetry is in actual fact a departure f=
rom spherical symmetry. And I suspect that from this starting position bila=
teral symmetry should be easier to reach (and it is maybe biologically more=
 plausible!?).

@Jeff: can you try that for us? :-)

From this perspective,=
 complexification (or diversification) would mean breaking the symmetry  ra=
ther than approaching it, which seems to me more natural. But as I said, I =
am not familiar with the literature in this area.

Best,
Martin
